trans-unit.source: How to use multiple clients with a single mobile service backend | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: How to use multiple clients with a single mobile service backend | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use a single mobile service back-end from multiple client apps that target different mobile platforms, including Windows Store and Windows Phone.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use a single mobile service back-end from multiple client apps that target different mobile platforms, including Windows Store and Windows Phone.

trans-unit.source: Supporting multiple device platforms from a single mobile service
trans-unit.target: Supporting multiple device platforms from a single mobile service

trans-unit.source: One of the major benefits of using Azure Mobile Services in your mobile app development is the ability to use a single backend service that supports your app on multiple client platforms.
trans-unit.target: One of the major benefits of using Azure Mobile Services in your mobile app development is the ability to use a single backend service that supports your app on multiple client platforms.

trans-unit.source: Mobile Services provides native client libraries for all major device platforms, which makes it easier to develop apps using a single backend service and by using cross-platform developer tools.
trans-unit.target: Mobile Services provides native client libraries for all major device platforms, which makes it easier to develop apps using a single backend service and by using cross-platform developer tools.

trans-unit.source: This topic discusses considerations for getting your app running on multiple client platforms while using a single mobile service backend.
trans-unit.target: This topic discusses considerations for getting your app running on multiple client platforms while using a single mobile service backend.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Cross-platform push notifications
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Cross-platform push notifications

trans-unit.source: Mobile Services uses Azure Notification Hubs for sending push notifications to your client apps on all major device platforms.
trans-unit.target: Mobile Services uses Azure Notification Hubs for sending push notifications to your client apps on all major device platforms.

trans-unit.source: Notification Hubs provide a consistent and unified infrastructure for creating and managing device registrations and for sending cross-platform push notifications.
trans-unit.target: Notification Hubs provide a consistent and unified infrastructure for creating and managing device registrations and for sending cross-platform push notifications.

trans-unit.source: Notification Hubs supports sending push notifications by using the following platform-specific notification services:
trans-unit.target: Notification Hubs supports sending push notifications by using the following platform-specific notification services:

trans-unit.source: Apple Push Notification Service (APNS) for iOS apps
trans-unit.target: Apple Push Notification Service (APNS) for iOS apps

trans-unit.source: Google Cloud Messaging (GCM) service for Android apps
trans-unit.target: Google Cloud Messaging (GCM) service for Android apps

trans-unit.source: Windows Notification Service (WNS) for Windows Store, Windows Phone 8.1 Store, and universal Windows apps
trans-unit.target: Windows Notification Service (WNS) for Windows Store, Windows Phone 8.1 Store, and universal Windows apps

trans-unit.source: Microsoft Push Notification Service (MPNS) for Windows Phone Silverlight apps
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Push Notification Service (MPNS) for Windows Phone Silverlight apps

trans-unit.source: Notification Hubs does not currently support using WNS to send push notifications to Windows Phone Silverlight 8.1 apps.
trans-unit.target: Notification Hubs does not currently support using WNS to send push notifications to Windows Phone Silverlight 8.1 apps.

trans-unit.source: You must use MPNS to send notifications to Silverlight and Windows Phone 8.0 and 7.0 apps.
trans-unit.target: You must use MPNS to send notifications to Silverlight and Windows Phone 8.0 and 7.0 apps.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Azure Notification Hubs].
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Azure Notification Hubs].

trans-unit.source: Client registrations are created by using the register function in the platform-specific Mobile Services client library or by using the Mobile Services REST APIs.
trans-unit.target: Client registrations are created by using the register function in the platform-specific Mobile Services client library or by using the Mobile Services REST APIs.

trans-unit.source: Notification Hubs supports two kinds of device registrations:
trans-unit.target: Notification Hubs supports two kinds of device registrations:

trans-unit.source: Native registrationNative registrations are tailored to the platform-specific push notification service.
trans-unit.target: Native registrationNative registrations are tailored to the platform-specific push notification service.

trans-unit.source: When sending notifications to devices registered using native registrations, you must call platform-specific APIs in your mobile service.
trans-unit.target: When sending notifications to devices registered using native registrations, you must call platform-specific APIs in your mobile service.

trans-unit.source: To send a notification to devices on multiple platforms requires multiple platform-specific calls.
trans-unit.target: To send a notification to devices on multiple platforms requires multiple platform-specific calls.

trans-unit.source: Template registrationNotification Hubs also supports platform-specific template registrations.
trans-unit.target: Template registrationNotification Hubs also supports platform-specific template registrations.

trans-unit.source: By using template registrations, you can use a single API call to send a notification to your app running on any registered platform.
trans-unit.target: By using template registrations, you can use a single API call to send a notification to your app running on any registered platform.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Send cross-platform notifications to users].
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Send cross-platform notifications to users].

trans-unit.source: An error occurs when trying to send a message to a native device platform for which no device registrations exists.
trans-unit.target: An error occurs when trying to send a message to a native device platform for which no device registrations exists.

trans-unit.source: This error does not occur when sending template notifications.
trans-unit.target: This error does not occur when sending template notifications.

trans-unit.source: Tables in the following sections link to the client-specific tutorials that show you how to implement push notifications from both .NET and JavaScript backend mobile services.
trans-unit.target: Tables in the following sections link to the client-specific tutorials that show you how to implement push notifications from both .NET and JavaScript backend mobile services.

trans-unit.source: .NET backend
trans-unit.target: .NET backend

trans-unit.source: In a .NET backend mobile service, you send notifications by calling the [SendAsync] method on the <link><linkText>PushClient</linkText><title></title></link> object obtained from the <link><linkText>ApiServices.Push</linkText><title></title></link> property.
trans-unit.target: In a .NET backend mobile service, you send notifications by calling the [SendAsync] method on the <link><linkText>PushClient</linkText><title></title></link> object obtained from the <link><linkText>ApiServices.Push</linkText><title></title></link> property.

trans-unit.source: The push notification sent (native or template) depends on the specific <link><linkText>IPushMessage</linkText><title></title></link>-derived object that is passed to the [SendAsync] method, as shown in the following table:
trans-unit.target: The push notification sent (native or template) depends on the specific <link><linkText>IPushMessage</linkText><title></title></link>-derived object that is passed to the [SendAsync] method, as shown in the following table:

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Cross-platform app development
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Cross-platform app development

trans-unit.source: Developing native mobile device apps for all of the major mobile device platforms requires you (or your organization) to have expertise in at least Objective-C, Java, and C# or JavaScript programming languages.
trans-unit.target: Developing native mobile device apps for all of the major mobile device platforms requires you (or your organization) to have expertise in at least Objective-C, Java, and C# or JavaScript programming languages.

trans-unit.source: Because of the expense of developing across these disparate platforms, some developers choose a fully web browser-based experience for their apps.
trans-unit.target: Because of the expense of developing across these disparate platforms, some developers choose a fully web browser-based experience for their apps.

trans-unit.source: However, such web-based experiences cannot access most of the native resources that provide the rich experience that users have come to expect on their mobile devices.
trans-unit.target: However, such web-based experiences cannot access most of the native resources that provide the rich experience that users have come to expect on their mobile devices.

trans-unit.source: Cross-platform tools are available that provide a richer native experience on a mobile device, while still sharing a single code base, usually JavaScript.
trans-unit.target: Cross-platform tools are available that provide a richer native experience on a mobile device, while still sharing a single code base, usually JavaScript.

trans-unit.source: Mobile Services makes it easy to create and manage a backend service for cross-platform app development platforms by providing quickstart tutorials for the following development platforms:
trans-unit.target: Mobile Services makes it easy to create and manage a backend service for cross-platform app development platforms by providing quickstart tutorials for the following development platforms:

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>**Appcelerator**</linkText><title></title></link><html></html>Appcelerator lets you use JavaScript to develop a single app that is compiled to run as native on all mobile device platforms.
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>**Appcelerator**</linkText><title></title></link><html></html>Appcelerator lets you use JavaScript to develop a single app that is compiled to run as native on all mobile device platforms.

trans-unit.source: This provides a rich user experience in UI, access to all native device resources, and native app performance.
trans-unit.target: This provides a rich user experience in UI, access to all native device resources, and native app performance.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the <link><linkText>Appcelerator tutorial[appcelerator]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the <link><linkText>Appcelerator tutorial[appcelerator]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: **PhoneGap**/**Cordova**PhoneGap (a distribution of the Apache Cordova project) is a free and open source framework that lets you use standardized web APIs, HTML and JavaScript to develop a single app that runs on Android, iOS and Windows devices.
trans-unit.target: **PhoneGap**/**Cordova**PhoneGap (a distribution of the Apache Cordova project) is a free and open source framework that lets you use standardized web APIs, HTML and JavaScript to develop a single app that runs on Android, iOS and Windows devices.

trans-unit.source: PhoneGap provides a web view based UI, but with a user experience enhanced by accessing native resources on the device, such as such as push notifications, the accelerometer, camera, storage, geolocation, and the in-app browser.
trans-unit.target: PhoneGap provides a web view based UI, but with a user experience enhanced by accessing native resources on the device, such as such as push notifications, the accelerometer, camera, storage, geolocation, and the in-app browser.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the <link><linkText>PhoneGap quickstart tutorial[phonegap]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the <link><linkText>PhoneGap quickstart tutorial[phonegap]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio now also enables you to build cross-platform Cordova apps by using the Multi-Device Hybrid Apps extension for Visual Studio, which is pre-release software.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio now also enables you to build cross-platform Cordova apps by using the Multi-Device Hybrid Apps extension for Visual Studio, which is pre-release software.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>Getting Started with Multi-Device Hybrid Apps Using HTML and JavaScript</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>Getting Started with Multi-Device Hybrid Apps Using HTML and JavaScript</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>**Sencha Touch**</linkText><title></title></link><html></html>Sencha Touch provides a set of controls, optimized for touch screens, that provide a like-native experience on a wide variety of mobile devices from a single HTML and JavaScript code base.
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>**Sencha Touch**</linkText><title></title></link><html></html>Sencha Touch provides a set of controls, optimized for touch screens, that provide a like-native experience on a wide variety of mobile devices from a single HTML and JavaScript code base.

trans-unit.source: Sencha Touch can be used along with PhoneGap or Cordova libraries to provide users access to native device resources.
trans-unit.target: Sencha Touch can be used along with PhoneGap or Cordova libraries to provide users access to native device resources.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the <link><linkText>Sencha Touch quickstart tutorial[sencha]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the <link><linkText>Sencha Touch quickstart tutorial[sencha]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>**Xamarin**</linkText><title></title></link><html></html>Xamarin lets you create fully native apps for both iOS and Android devices, with fully native UI and access to all device resources.
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>**Xamarin**</linkText><title></title></link><html></html>Xamarin lets you create fully native apps for both iOS and Android devices, with fully native UI and access to all device resources.

trans-unit.source: Xamarin apps are coded in C# instead of Objective-C and Java.
trans-unit.target: Xamarin apps are coded in C# instead of Objective-C and Java.

trans-unit.source: This enables .NET developers to publish apps to iOS and Android and share code from Windows projects.
trans-unit.target: This enables .NET developers to publish apps to iOS and Android and share code from Windows projects.

trans-unit.source: Xamarin provides a fully native user experience on both iOS and Android devices from C# code.
trans-unit.target: Xamarin provides a fully native user experience on both iOS and Android devices from C# code.

trans-unit.source: This enables you to reuse some of your Mobile Services code from Windows apps on iOS and Android devices.
trans-unit.target: This enables you to reuse some of your Mobile Services code from Windows apps on iOS and Android devices.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>Xamarin development</linkText><title></title></link> below.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>Xamarin development</linkText><title></title></link> below.

trans-unit.source: You can build Xamarin apps using either Xamarin Studio or Visual Studio 2013.
trans-unit.target: You can build Xamarin apps using either Xamarin Studio or Visual Studio 2013.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>Cross-Platform Development in Visual Studio</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>Cross-Platform Development in Visual Studio</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Sharing and reusing code in Visual Studio projects
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Sharing and reusing code in Visual Studio projects

trans-unit.source: Mobile Services includes a .NET client library, which is a .NET Framework Portable Class Library (PCL) that supports development on all Windows platforms.
trans-unit.target: Mobile Services includes a .NET client library, which is a .NET Framework Portable Class Library (PCL) that supports development on all Windows platforms.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [How to use a .NET client with Mobile Services].
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [How to use a .NET client with Mobile Services].

trans-unit.source: This makes it easy to reuse the same Mobile Services code, such as for data access or authentication, in multiple C# projects.
trans-unit.target: This makes it easy to reuse the same Mobile Services code, such as for data access or authentication, in multiple C# projects.

trans-unit.source: One general approach for sharing and reusing your C# code between projects is to implement the Model-View-ViewModel (MVVM) pattern and share assemblies across multiple platforms.
trans-unit.target: One general approach for sharing and reusing your C# code between projects is to implement the Model-View-ViewModel (MVVM) pattern and share assemblies across multiple platforms.

trans-unit.source: You can implement the model and view model classes in a Portable Class Library project in Visual Studio, and then create views that are customized for different platforms.
trans-unit.target: You can implement the model and view model classes in a Portable Class Library project in Visual Studio, and then create views that are customized for different platforms.

trans-unit.source: The model code, common across platforms, may (as an example) retrieve the data from a source such as your mobile service in a platform-agnostic manner.
trans-unit.target: The model code, common across platforms, may (as an example) retrieve the data from a source such as your mobile service in a platform-agnostic manner.

trans-unit.source: The MSDN Library provides an <html></html>overview and example<html></html>, discussion of <html></html>API differences<html></html>, an example of <html></html>using portable class libraries to implement the MVVM pattern<html></html>, additional <html></html>prescriptive guidance<html></html>, and information about <html></html>managing resources<html></html> in portable class library projects.
trans-unit.target: The MSDN Library provides an <html></html>overview and example<html></html>, discussion of <html></html>API differences<html></html>, an example of <html></html>using portable class libraries to implement the MVVM pattern<html></html>, additional <html></html>prescriptive guidance<html></html>, and information about <html></html>managing resources<html></html> in portable class library projects.

trans-unit.source: In addition to this general guidance, Visual Studio also provides specific facilities for reusing your mobile services code across multiple client app projects, which are discussed in the following sections.
trans-unit.target: In addition to this general guidance, Visual Studio also provides specific facilities for reusing your mobile services code across multiple client app projects, which are discussed in the following sections.

trans-unit.source: For more general information about using Visual Studio 2013 to build cross-platform apps, see <link><linkText>Cross-Platform Development in Visual Studio</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more general information about using Visual Studio 2013 to build cross-platform apps, see <link><linkText>Cross-Platform Development in Visual Studio</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Universal Windows apps
trans-unit.target: Universal Windows apps

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio 2013 Update 2 adds support for universal Windows app projects.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio 2013 Update 2 adds support for universal Windows app projects.

trans-unit.source: Universal apps are solutions that include both Windows Store 8.1 and Windows Phone Store 8.1 app projects along with a shared code project.
trans-unit.target: Universal apps are solutions that include both Windows Store 8.1 and Windows Phone Store 8.1 app projects along with a shared code project.

trans-unit.source: In this kind of project, shared code is treated as if it is part of both the Windows Store and Windows Phone projects.
trans-unit.target: In this kind of project, shared code is treated as if it is part of both the Windows Store and Windows Phone projects.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Building universal Windows apps for all Windows devices].
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Building universal Windows apps for all Windows devices].

trans-unit.source: Universal Windows apps can be written in both C#/XAML and JavaScript/HTML.
trans-unit.target: Universal Windows apps can be written in both C#/XAML and JavaScript/HTML.

trans-unit.source: By default, the Mobile Service quickstart tab in the [Azure Management portal] generates a universal Windows app version of the TodoList sample app to get you started.
trans-unit.target: By default, the Mobile Service quickstart tab in the [Azure Management portal] generates a universal Windows app version of the TodoList sample app to get you started.

trans-unit.source: You can choose to download either a C#/XAML or a JavaScript/HTML version of the project.
trans-unit.target: You can choose to download either a C#/XAML or a JavaScript/HTML version of the project.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>Get started with Mobile Services</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>Get started with Mobile Services</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The C# version of the quickstart app project from the portal shares the MainPage.xaml.cs code-behind page but doesn't use a view model.
trans-unit.target: The C# version of the quickstart app project from the portal shares the MainPage.xaml.cs code-behind page but doesn't use a view model.

trans-unit.source: For an example of the TodoList app as a universal Windows app project in C# that uses MVVM, see [Universal Windows app project for Azure Mobile Services using MVVM].
trans-unit.target: For an example of the TodoList app as a universal Windows app project in C# that uses MVVM, see [Universal Windows app project for Azure Mobile Services using MVVM].

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Xamarin development
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Xamarin development

trans-unit.source: You can leverage your Visual Studio and C# development experience, by using Xamarin and either Visual Studio or Xamarin Studio to develop apps for iOS and Android.
trans-unit.target: You can leverage your Visual Studio and C# development experience, by using Xamarin and either Visual Studio or Xamarin Studio to develop apps for iOS and Android.

trans-unit.source: Xamarin uses a cross-platform implementation of the .NET Framework that lets you use C# code to develop iOS and Android apps.
trans-unit.target: Xamarin uses a cross-platform implementation of the .NET Framework that lets you use C# code to develop iOS and Android apps.

trans-unit.source: By using Xamarin, you can leverage existing code from your Windows projects that uses the Mobile Services .NET client library to access your mobile service.
trans-unit.target: By using Xamarin, you can leverage existing code from your Windows projects that uses the Mobile Services .NET client library to access your mobile service.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>Cross-Platform Development in Visual Studio</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>Cross-Platform Development in Visual Studio</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: To get started building Xamarin apps that use Mobile Services, see the Xamarin quickstart tutorials (<link><linkText>iOS</linkText><title></title></link> / <link><linkText>Android</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To get started building Xamarin apps that use Mobile Services, see the Xamarin quickstart tutorials (<link><linkText>iOS</linkText><title></title></link> / <link><linkText>Android</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Windows Store and Windows Phone Silverlight apps
trans-unit.target: Windows Store and Windows Phone Silverlight apps

trans-unit.source: In Windows Phone 8.1, you can choose to use the previous Silverlight-based XAML for developing apps or use the Windows Runtime-based XAML, which enables the development of universal Windows apps.
trans-unit.target: In Windows Phone 8.1, you can choose to use the previous Silverlight-based XAML for developing apps or use the Windows Runtime-based XAML, which enables the development of universal Windows apps.

trans-unit.source: For more information about Windows Phone 8.1 Silverlight apps and Windows Phone Store 8.1 apps, see [What's next for Windows Phone 8 developers].
trans-unit.target: For more information about Windows Phone 8.1 Silverlight apps and Windows Phone Store 8.1 apps, see [What's next for Windows Phone 8 developers].

trans-unit.source: The Mobile Services .NET client library supports both Windows Phone Store 8.1 and Windows Phone Silverlight 8.1 apps.
trans-unit.target: The Mobile Services .NET client library supports both Windows Phone Store 8.1 and Windows Phone Silverlight 8.1 apps.

trans-unit.source: Since both Windows Runtime and Windows Phone Silverlight apps cannot be built from the same project, you should consider a code reuse strategy such as PCL and MVVM described above.
trans-unit.target: Since both Windows Runtime and Windows Phone Silverlight apps cannot be built from the same project, you should consider a code reuse strategy such as PCL and MVVM described above.

trans-unit.source: In order to use single sign-on client authentication using Microsoft Account in both Windows Runtime and Windows Phone Silverlight apps, you must register the Windows Runtime app on the Windows Store dashboard first.
trans-unit.target: In order to use single sign-on client authentication using Microsoft Account in both Windows Runtime and Windows Phone Silverlight apps, you must register the Windows Runtime app on the Windows Store dashboard first.

trans-unit.source: This is because once you create a Live Connect registration for Windows Phone, you cannot create one for Windows Store.
trans-unit.target: This is because once you create a Live Connect registration for Windows Phone, you cannot create one for Windows Store.

trans-unit.source: For more information about how to do this, please read the topic Authenticate your Windows Store app with Live Connect single sign-on (Windows Store[sso windows store]/Windows Phone[sso windows phone]).
trans-unit.target: For more information about how to do this, please read the topic Authenticate your Windows Store app with Live Connect single sign-on (Windows Store[sso windows store]/Windows Phone[sso windows phone]).
